Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Chewing Gum for Postoperative Recovery after Colorectal Resection

Participants.evidence: Eligible patients were adults scheduled for elective colorectal resection. Participants were recruited from five UK hospitals

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to standard postoperative care with or without chewing gum

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to determine whether chewing gum reduces the length of hospital stay (LOS) after colorectal resection.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was LOS, measured from the date of operation to discharge.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with concealed allocation.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for participants or outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 402 patients were analysed (199 in the gum group, 203 in the control group)

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 402 patients were analysed (199 in the gum group, 203 in the control group) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Median LOS was 7 days in both groups (hazard ratio 0.94, 95% CI 0.77 to 1.15; p = 0.557).

Harms.evidence: Participants in the gum group had worse quality of life at 6 and 12 weeks post-operation and more complications graded III or above (16 vs. 6) and deaths (11 vs. 0), none related to gum.
